title: 112_hr634
content: The "Debt Buy-Down Act of 2011" is designated for the reduction of public debt through amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It introduces a new part for the designation of amounts for debt reduction. The "Debt Buy-Down Act of 2011" allows individuals to designate up to 10% of their adjusted income tax liability to reduce public debt. This designation must be made when filing tax returns and is subtracted from the individual's income tax liability. The "Debt Buy-Down Act of 2011" allows individuals to designate up to 10% of their adjusted income tax liability to reduce public debt. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the date of the enactment of this Act. A new section, "SEC. 9512. PUBLIC DEBT REDUCTION TRUST FUND," is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States to pay off or buy back federal government obligations included in the public debt, excluding certain obligations held by specific funds. Amounts equivalent to designated funds are appropriated to the Trust Fund for this purpose. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established to pay off federal government obligations, and any amount paid from the fund shall be canceled and retired without reissuance. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established to pay off federal government obligations, with amendments applying to amounts received after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, a new section is added for sequestration to reduce the public debt. Sequestration will occur within 15 days after Congress adjourns, equivalent to the estimated aggregate amount designated under the Internal Revenue Code for the last taxable year. Sequestration will occur if the reduction in spending for a fiscal year is greater than the estimated aggregate amount designated under the Internal Revenue Code. Each account of the United States will be reduced by a calculated dollar amount. Sequestration involves reducing spending for a fiscal year if it exceeds the estimated amount designated under the Internal Revenue Code. Reductions are made to each account by a calculated dollar amount, with certain exemptions such as benefits under the Social Security Act and payments for net interest. Reports on these reductions are required under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a new item in the table. The Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a new item in the table regarding the Department of Treasury report to Congress estimating income tax designated for reducing the public debt. The Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a new item in the table regarding the Department of Treasury report to Congress estimating income tax designated for reducing the public debt. The preview reports shall include estimates for the aggregate amount designated under section 6097 of the Internal Revenue Code, reductions required under section 253A, and the sequestration percentage necessary to achieve the required reduction in accounts. Reports on sequestration to reduce the public debt are also required. The Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include reports on sequestration to reduce the public debt. The final reports must contain all information from the public debt taxation designation report. The Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include sequestration for reducing public debt. The amendments made by this section will remain effective until the first fiscal year without public debt.
